node.text:
The Arctic National Wildlife Refuge is home to more than 200 species of birds and is sacred land for the Gwich'in people—but it has never been in greater danger. On the Arctic Refuge Day of Action, learn more about this vast Alaskan wilderness and what you can do to help protect this critical habitat.

Join us in taking action to #ProtectTheArctic today: https://www.audubon.org/arcticrefuge

node.title: Why Birds Need the Arctic Refuge

node.text:
Did you know that the Boreal Forest is home to between 1-3 billion birds that nest in the region each year? Not only that: it’s a nature based climate solution, holding about 12% of land-based carbon reserves. Audubon is working closely with our chapters, members, and Indigenous partners to protect one of the largest intact forests left on planet Earth. 🌲

On #WorldMigratoryBirdDay, learn more about conservation efforts for North America’s bird nursery: audubon.org/borealforests

node.title: The Boreal Forest: A Bird Haven

node.text: Just in time for National Native Plant Month, we’re learning all about #PlantsForBirds with Audubon’s Dr. John Rowden (@johnrowden) and Christine Lin (@chrriscross)! Want to find the right native plants for your area? Check out audubon.org/plantsforbirds.

node.text:
Dr. Steve Kress, or “The Puffin Man” as some like to call him, found a way to bring Atlantic Puffins back to Maine four decades ago after the seabirds were nearly hunted to extinction. Hear the story behind Project Puffin (now known as the Seabird Institute) in this video.

Join the Seabird Institute to #SaveTheSeabirds and protect the places they need today: https://bit.ly/3ad8UFw

node.text:
We’re talking all things spring migration with Audubon’s David Ringer (@davidjeffreyringer) and Christine Lin (@chrriscross). 

Want to learn even more? Tune in to our next episode of “I Saw A Bird” next Wednesday (3/31) at 7 pm ET! RSVP here: https://bit.ly/3lS3XGC

node.text:
Did you know that the Great Lakes provide drinking water to 40 million people and its coastal habitats support more than 350 bird species? As climate change, coastal development, and invasive species threaten these communities and habitats, @audubongreatlakes is ready with a bold plan.

Our new report, Restoring the Great Lakes for Birds and People, uses science to pinpoint the highest-priority coastal regions for birds, water quality, and coastal resiliency—focusing conservation where it’s needed most. Learn more and join us on this journey: https://bit.ly/397ppSG

node.title: Protecting Birds in the Great Lakes

node.text:
The fierce and resilient Bald Eagle is a common sight today, but did you know the species was on the brink of extinction in the 1970s? Eagles recovered thanks to increased protections under the Endangered Species Act, but new rules would weaken it. 

Urge your members of Congress today to stand up for this critical law: https://bit.ly/3tjk9TH

node.title: How the Bald Eagle Made a Comeback

node.text: It’s not just wildlife that depend on the sagebrush steppe; so do people. Entire livelihoods, businesses, and cultures are tied to this Western ecosystem. But an invasive grass is spreading across millions of acres. See how it’s impacting ranches like @winecup_gamble_ranch, hunters, and the @shoshonetribe in this new video from @audubonrockies. Then, tell Congress to take action to support cheatgrass control and sagebrush habitat restoration: http://audubon.org/cheatgrass

node.text: Audubon’s Seabird Institute works to restore Atlantic Puffin and other seabird populations to islands off the coast of Maine. Each summer, a team of research assistants live and conduct research on these islands. Listen in to learn about this experience. Want to apply to become a research assistant? Visit https://www.audubon.org/seabirdsummer

node.title: Audubon’s Seabird Institute Summer Field Research Program

node.text: Niki loves dogs and plovers—but knows they need to keep their distance as breeding season is around the corner. Join her as she helps #ShareTheShore and protects Snowy Plovers on the West Coast! @sinceresugar

node.text: Swans made of broken glass and ceramic appear to fly out of a 20-foot mosaic on a corner in upper Manhattan—serving as both an inspiring addition to a community hit hard by COVID-19 and a sobering reminder that the species, after bouncing back from near extinction, is now threatened by climate change. Learn how artists Carlos Pinto (@pintocards) & John Sear created the 20-foot mural: https://bit.ly/2XL2dna #AudubonMuralProject

node.text:
2020 may have felt like a long year, but it was no different in terms of the amazing and important things we accomplished. Join us in taking a look back—and a look forward.

Sign up to advocate for the birds you love and the places they need to make 2021 even better: https://bit.ly/3mnAZx0

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Audubon Society in Maumee Bay State Park with @christylfrank. May be an image of bird and nature.

node.text:
For the first time since 1938, Piping Plovers are nesting in Ohio—and there are babies on board! 🐣⁠
⁠
Meet Nellie and her partner Nish, the first nesting pair of Piping Plovers in Ohio in 83 years. The pair made their home on the shores of Lake Erie in June, and recently became parents to a brood of four chicks on July 1st. It’s an optimistic sign of the critically endangered species’ return to the Great Lakes. Moreover, it’s evidence that #SharetheShore works. We applaud the work of volunteers from @bsbobird for educating the public on how they can protect the Piping Plover’s habitat and help prolong the survival of this cherished shorebird species.⁠
⁠
Get the details on Nish and Nellie’s backstory by tapping the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Nish the Piping Plover attempts to court Nellie in Maumee Bay State Park, May, 2021. 📷: Christy Frank (@christylfrank)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Audubon Society in Grand Isle, Louisiana. May be an image of nature and body of water.

node.text:
Deliberately harming the planet might soon be tried as ‘ecocide’ in the International Criminal Court (ICC), the same international court that prosecutes war crimes and genocide. After years of deliberation, an international panel of lawyers released its first legal definition. ⁠
⁠
If added to the court’s statute and ratified, member states of the ICC could bring criminal charges to individuals—such as corporate CEOs and heads of state—for committing ecocide in their territories. It’s an important step in bringing accountability to some of the world’s biggest polluters. While enforcement is a long way off, the ratification could see hundreds of energy and fossil fuel companies recalibrate their strategies.⁠
⁠
To learn more about this effort to stop widespread environmental destruction, Audubon caught up with Jojo Mehta (@jojomehta), a co-founder of Stop Ecocide (@ecocidelaw), the organization leading this effort. Read the full interview by checking out the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
A Brown Pelican drenched in oil following the BP Deepwater Horizon oil spill, Louisiana, June, 2010. 📷: Charlie Riedel (@charlie_riedel_pix)/AP

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Audubon Society in Novi, Michigan. May be an image of bird and nature.

node.text:
How do you outsmart one of the speediest birds? With plenty of free time on your hands and some ingenuity, of course.⁠
⁠
For decades, Adrienne Elliot has enjoyed watching a wide variety of birds in her yard, but always found it challenging to photograph them. This all changed during the COVID-19 lockdowns when she thought to attach some camouflage fabric to her sliding glass door and cut a hole for her camera lens. She also moved some of her feeders and added perches for the birds to land on. Since Downy Woodpeckers move so quickly, she was elated to get the shot.⁠
⁠
This shot shows a woodpecker perched on a branch that cuts across the frame horizontally, its black-and-white-striped back facing the camera. The bird’s body aligns perfectly with the branch. A red stripe across the back of its head stands out against a blurred beige background.⁠
⁠
Adrienne’s satisfying shot made this year’s #AudubonPhotographyAwards top 100 list.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Audubon Society in Nanchang, Jiangxi. May be an image of wading bird and nature.

node.text:
Great Egret chicks are very demanding, and both mates have to work hard to care for the feisty newborns! 🐥 In China’s Xiangshan Forest Park, hundreds of adults arrive in the early spring to breed, building their nests at the top of fir trees. Females lay one to six eggs and both mates take turns incubating them. The nearby rivers and lakes provide abundant fish to feed the parents and their chicks.⁠
⁠
Two springs ago, Xianwei Zeng spent three weeks at Xiangshang Forest Park observing and photographing the Great Egrets. In order to get low-angle shots, he stood on a farmer’s house. He usually saw only one parent feeding the chicks at a time, but on this particular rainy day, both adults fed the babies simultaneously. He quickly snapped a few shots of the family, capturing them all in one frame.⁠
⁠
In the final shot, the Great Egret parents stand in a nest made of sticks, wispy feathers coming off their backs and their necks crisscrossing as they bend low to feed three fuzzy chicks. Two of the chicks raise their yellow bills up to receive a regurgitated meal.⁠
⁠
Xianwei’s amusing photograph made this year’s #AudubonPhotographyAwards top 100 list.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Audubon Society on August 05, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, wading bird and nature.

node.text:
Among the rich wildlife that calls Audubon’s Pine Island Sanctuary on Currituck Sound home, there are several species of birds well-adapted to living hidden lives in the tall marsh grasses. Known as “secretive marsh birds,” they’re more often heard than seen, but their presence is indicative of the ecosystem’s larger health. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
This past spring, staff and volunteers from @audubon_nc spent their early mornings and evenings venturing to the Pine Island Sanctuary to look for five priority secretive marsh bird species: the King Rail, Virginia Rail, Black Rail, Least Bittern, and Common Gallinule. They hopped into groups in small boats; one person playing the calls of the target species in hopes of eliciting a response, the other filling in a data sheet. Since secretive marsh birds depend on a healthy ecosystem to survive, the survey data collected will feed into larger regional efforts to understand these birds and protect their wetland habitats. If we know what’s happening with them, we can better understand how to preserve the marsh for both wildlife and the people who live along the Currituck Sound.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
To learn more about the results of the survey—and how it can set the stage for more conservation work for the marshes on North Carolina’s coast—tap the link in our bio.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
1️⃣ - A King Rail with its beak open. 📷: Robert Gundy (@florida_naturalist) /Audubon Photography Awards⁠⁠
2️⃣ - An Audubon staffer plays a marsh bird recording to help elicit a response. 📷: Ben Graham/Audubon⁠⁠
3️⃣ - An Audubon staffer uses binoculars to look for birds in the tall marsh grasses. 📷: Ben Graham/Audubon⁠⁠⁠⁠

Photo by National Audubon Society on August 05, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, nature and grass.
Photo by National Audubon Society on August 05, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and nature.
Photo by National Audubon Society in Chuckanut Bay with @rrhys_l. May be an image of bird and nature.

node.text:
Rhys Logan (@rrhys_l) had never seen a Rhinoceros Auklet in person before, perhaps because the bird is nocturnal and typically nests in hard-to-access places. When he encountered this pair while kayaking in Chuckanut Bay, WA, he was surprised by their penguin-like appearance—even though they’re related to puffins (talk about auk-ward).⁠
⁠
After the raucous din of thousands of nearby gulls calling and diving around them subsided, these two auklets calmly waded closer to him, enjoying the sundown as much as he was. Surrounded by rippling water colored golden by the sunset, he captured two silhouetted Rhinoceros Auklets swimming side by side in the bay, their profiles showing their horn-like bills.⁠
⁠
Rhys’s eye-catching photograph was selected to be in this year’s #AudubonPhotographyAwards top 100 list.

node.text:
How much do you know about owls and their calls? You might be surprised to find that a few are...a bit out of the ordinary! Guess along with the video as we learn a few facts about these fierce birds of flight.

Learn more about owls at http://audubon.org/owls.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Audubon Society in Bosque del Apache National Wildlife Refuge with @smartipix. May be an image of goose and nature.

node.text:
Some images have the power to transport you to a certain place in time. For Marti Phillips (@smartipix), witnessing thousands of Snow Geese fill a twilight sky brought her to an era where so much of the United State’s rich habitats had not yet been destroyed.⁠
⁠
Just as she arrived at the Bosque Del Apache National Wildlife Refuge for the first time, Marti was treated to this breathtaking sight. As the sun set, she heard the explosive sound of thousands of Snow Geese taking off from the water in unison, t​​he white of their wings reflecting the fading light. Below them, a swoop of Sandhill Cranes stood like sentinels in the brown grasses of a wetland, still water surrounding them.⁠
⁠
Marti’s ethereal photo made this year’s #AudubonPhotographyAwards top 100 list.

location.name: Bosque del Apache National Wildlife Refuge

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Audubon Society on August 03, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, child, standing, tree and outdoors.

node.text:
For BIPOC, the painful history of racism endured while outdoors—including Baltimore's long-established history of racial redlining—can be a barrier to enjoying it to the fullest. But one Baltimore woman wants to change that by giving budding naturalists of color a safe place to explore their city’s environment. ⁠
⁠
Atiya Wells—pediatric nurse, naturalist, and founder of @backyard_basecamp—transformed an abandoned seven-acre lot near her home in northeast Baltimore into a vibrant farm, habitat, and garden serving her community’s needs. Her land reclamation project, called BLISS (Baltimore Living in Sustainable Simplicity) Meadows, created a deliberate space where Black and brown people could benefit from the land where they live and help heal the wounds of experiencing systemic racism through nature. All of the staff live in the neighborhood they serve and understand first-hand the issues the area faces.⁠
⁠
BLISS Meadows provides both fresh produce to help combat Baltimore’s food deserts as well as lush green land that attracts a variety of common Baltimore birds, from hummingbirds, cardinals, and robins, to a Great Blue Heron by the plot’s pond. Atiya’s project is a remarkable example of how shared green spaces can not only protect nature and wildlife, but foster solidarity amongst neighbors. The best conservation work happens when everyone involved feels welcomed, safe, and included.⁠
⁠
To read more about Atiya’s inspirational land reclamation project, tap the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Atiya Wells, the founder and executive director of BLISS Meadows. 📷: Sean Mancho (@nkwen.star)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Audubon Society on August 02, 2021. May be an image of bird and nature.

node.text:
When you think of a songbird, do you mainly conjure images of a gently twittering flier like the Veery? The general public throws the term around loosely, but a bird can still be a songbird even if its song isn’t very pretty.⁠
⁠
All songbirds belong to a suborder of passerines called the oscine, which includes over 4,000 species, from delicate singers such as the Wood Thrush and the Golden-crowned Kinglet, to guttural squawkers like the American Crow and the Common Raven. What they all have in common is a specialized organ that enables them to produce sound and learn their songs from adult tutors. Songbirds can even slightly alter their tunes over time! 🎶⁠
⁠
Songbirds have plenty of other special qualities—tap the link in our bio to learn even more of them.⁠
⁠
A Veery perched on a moss-covered log in the midst of song. 📷: William Leaman/Alamy

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Audubon Society in Flossmoor, Illinois with @sharon.dobben. May be an image of bird and nature.

node.text:
The cabin fever brought on by the COVID-19 shutdowns last year inspired many to go outside, grab their binoculars or cameras, and look for birds right in their own backyard. For Sharon Dobben (@sharon.dobben), last May’s spring migration was an especially welcome distraction. On one particular evening, she spotted a warbler in the yard and quickly grabbed her camera, and hustled outside, but a Baltimore Oriole singing its heart out distracted her. ⁠
⁠
She spotted it three backyards away perched on a high branch of a tall eastern white pine. Although she only got two shots before it took off, she successfully captured the oriole’s orange and black against the greens and blues of the background. The bird is small against a blue sky filled with white clouds, but its vibrant colors make it stand out against the sky and tree’s green needles. Hearing the oriole singing that evening was a perfect way to round off Sharon’s day.⁠
⁠
Sharon’s vivid photo was included in this year’s #AudubonPhotographyAwards top 100 list.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by National Audubon Society on August 01, 2021 tagging @benknoot. May be an image of bird and nature.

node.text:
The wonderfully odd mating ritual of the male Andean Cock-of-the-Rock makes them some of the most eligible bachelors in the tropical bird world. During the elaborate courtship dance that occurs every spring, males puff themselves up to an absurd degree, aggressively flap their wings, and hop from branch to branch while making loud twanging noises, in hopes of attracting a female—or several. Gathering on open patches of ground called “leks,” male Andean Cock-of-the-Rocks gather in numbers to compete for females. When one shows up, the activity of the males turns up to a frenzy as they vie for her attention.⁠
⁠
Want to discover some other birds’ extreme mating rituals? Tap the link in our bio to learn more from our resident bird expert Kenn Kaufman. ☝️⁠
⁠
A male Andean Cock-of-the-Rock quickly flaps its wings to prepare for a mating ritual. 📷: Ben Knoot (@benknoot)/Audubon Photography Awards
